questions.text: Blood group AB is denoted by which colour label
questions.solution: Correct Answer (C) Blood Group Color Coding Blood bags and vials are color-coded to prevent errors in blood transfusion. This system helps medical professionals quickly identify the blood type without having to read the label. Each of the four major ABO blood groups has a specific color assigned to it: A: Yellow B: Pink O: Blue AB: White

questions.text: All are true about FFP except
questions.solution: Correct Answer (C) Can be stored for 5 years • Fresh frozen plasma (FFP) is prepared by separating citrated plasma from whole blood and freezing it within 8 hours of collection or by freezing citrated apheresis plasma within 6 hours of collection. • Each unit of FFP prepared from whole blood contains approximately 200 ml of plasma. • Apheresis plasma may be packaged into 200- or 400-ml bags. • FFP may be stored at -18°C or below for up to 1 year. • Under these conditions, there is minimal loss of activity of the labile coagulation factors V and VIII. • One milliliter of FFP contains approximately one unit of coagulation factor activity. After thawing, • FFP may be stored in the refrigerator for up to 24 hours before use

questions.text: Interval between 2 blood donations should be at least
questions.solution: Correct Answer (C) 12 weeks • The interval between two blood donations should be at least 12 weeks. • At least 48 hours must elapse after plasma pheresis or Cytapheresis before whole blood is collected from a donor • Apheresis should be done only after 90days of whole blood collection or in an event when red cells are not returned at the end of pheresis

questions.text: Platelets can be stored at 22-25 deg C with agitation for how many days?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) 5 days Platelets are typically stored at a temperature range of 22-25°C with continuous agitation to maintain their viability. The recommended storage duration for platelets under these conditions is 5 days. Agitation helps to prevent clumping and maintains the platelets in a usable state, ensuring that they are functional for transfusion purposes. Beyond this period, platelet functionality begins to decline, and they may no longer be effective for clinical use. Incorrect Responses: B. 7 days: While some platelet storage systems might aim to extend the shelf life, the standard maximum storage period for platelets at 22-25°C with agitation is 5 days. Storing for 7 days would not maintain the necessary quality for transfusion. C. 21 days: 21 days is the typical storage time for red blood cells, not platelets. Red blood cells are stored at 2-6°C, which preserves their integrity for a much longer period, but platelets require higher temperatures and agitation, which limits their storage to 5 days. D. 35 days: 35 days is far beyond the typical storage limit for platelets. Platelets have a much shorter shelf life compared to other blood products like red blood cells and plasma, and they cannot remain viable for this length of time.

questions.text: Patient comes to ER with severe bleeding. Blood group is not known. Which group FFP will you give to the patient
questions.solution: Correct Answer (C) O +ve AB +ve Fresh Frozen Plasma • FFP is plasma prepared from whole blood, either from the primary centrifugation of whole blood into red cells and plasma or from a secondary centrifugation of platelet rich plasma. • The plasma is rapidly frozen to –25°C or colder within 8 hours of collection and contains normal plasma levels of stable clotting factors, albumin, immunoglobulin and • Factor VIII at a level of at least 70% of normal fresh plasma. • Should be ABO compatible. Universal Plasma Donor • Plasma components should be compatible with the ABO group of the recipient to avoid potential haemolysis caused by donor anti-A or anti-B. • Group AB individuals have neither anti-A nor anti-B antibodies in their plasma. Group AB plasma can therefore be given to patients of any ABO blood group and is often referred to as the universal plasma donor

questions.text: Patient with severe bleeding comes to emergency dept. As per your demand you get 4 platelet and 2 PRC units from blood bank. What should be the next step
questions.solution: Correct Answer (C) Transfuse PRC and store PC at room temp This is a straight forward practical question. In a severely bleeding patient first we have to transfuse PRBC. Now we will look at the platelets. • If you have a place to store platelets, platelets can be transfused without agitation in room temperature upto 24 hours. • Seeing the options, the it seems there is a facility to store platelets. • So PC will be the second to be transfused. In a setting where you don’t have storing option (like hospital ward), platelets should be transfused first for concern of bacterial contamination (since two options in the above questions are about storing platelets we presume there is a facility to store platelets)

questions.text: All are true about cryoprecipitate except
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) Thawed at -4 deg C CRYOPRECIPITATED AHF, OR CRYOPRECIPITATE • An extract of FFP that is enriched in high-molecular-weight plasma proteins. • It is prepared by thawing one unit of FFP at 1°C to 6°C • Each unit of this cryoprecipitate contains approximately 80 to 120 units of Factor VIII and at least 150 mg of fibrinogen. • It also contains factor XIII, fibronectin, and the high-molecular-weight multimers of vWF

questions.text: TRALI is seen within __ hours of transfusion
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) 6 Transfusion-Related Acute Lung Injury (TRALI) is a severe, life-threatening complication of blood transfusion characterized by acute respiratory distress and non-cardiogenic pulmonary edema. Key Features of TRALI: - Occurs within 6 hours of transfusion. - Presents with acute hypoxia, bilateral pulmonary infiltrates, and respiratory distress. - Not related to fluid overload or cardiac dysfunction (distinguishing it from TACO – Transfusion-Associated Circulatory Overload). Caused by donor antibodies (especially anti-HLA and anti-HNA) reacting with the recipient’s neutrophils, leading to pulmonary capillary damage.

questions.text: Most common complication of massive blood transfusion is
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) Hypothermia COMPLICATIONS OF MASSIVE BLOOD TRANSFUSION- • Hypothermia (most common complication) (cold fluid infusion and no thermal regulation) Hypokalemia (re entry into transfused RBCs, and stress hormone release) > Hyperkalemia (stored blood has more potassium and there is potassium retention due to loss of hydrogen ions in response to acidosis) • Metabolic alkalosis (citrate metabolism to bicarbonate) > acidosis • Hypocalcemia (rapid transfusion can cause citrate overload) • Hypomagnesemia (magnesium poor fluid) • Dilutional coagulopathy (most common cause of death following massive blood transfusion)

questions.text: Function of glucose in stored blood is
questions.solution: Correct Answer (C) Preventing hemolysis RED CELLS Additives • Sodium chloride: Isotonicity • Mannitol: reduces cell lysis • Dextrose: nutrition • Glucose: osmotic agent to reduce hemolysis • Phosphate: buffer solution • Adenine: for ATP maintenance, increases shelf life • Citrate: anti coagulant • One unit of red cells is often given in 1 to 4 hours, depending on the amount to be transfused and on the patient’s cardiovascular status. Infusion of a unit for longer than 4 hours is not recommended, as there is a risk of bacterial proliferation because the opened unit is at room temperature. Storage times • CPD : 21 days • CPDA : 35 days • SAGM : 42 days

questions.text: Any transfusion should be completed within __ hours of initiation
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) 4 hours Any transfusion should be completed within 4 hours of initiation to reduce the risk of bacterial growth and contamination. Once blood products are transfused, they are kept at room temperature, which allows any bacteria present to proliferate. Transfusing within 4 hours minimizes the risk of complications like transfusion-associated bacterial infections. This time frame is the standard recommended by most blood banks and medical institutions to ensure patient safety. Incorrect Responses: B. 6 hours: A transfusion completed after 6 hours exceeds the safe window and can pose a risk of bacterial contamination. Blood products are typically only safe for up to 4 hours at room temperature, and extending this to 6 hours is not advisable. C. 8 hours: 8 hours is even further beyond the recommended limit. After this time, the risk of complications such as bacterial growth increases significantly. Transfusion should not be carried out after such a long period, and this time frame is not within the safe guidelines. D. 10 hours: 10 hours is far too long for a transfusion to be considered safe. After 4 hours, blood products should be discarded if not used, as they could pose serious health risks to the patient. There is no clinical reason to extend transfusion to 10 hours.

questions.text: All of the following components should be mandatorily tested for compatibility except
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) Cryoprecipitate • Recipient should receive ABO type specific compatible whole blood or red blood cell components. • In the absence of ABO type specific blood, group O packed red cells should be transfused. • Platelet concentrate should be ABO and Rh(D) type specific with the recipient blood as far as possible • Leucocyte concentrate should be ABO and Rh(D) type specific or compatible with the recipient blood • ABO compatibility not mandatory for cryoprecipitate but mandatory for fresh frozen plasma

questions.text: In which of the following scenarios is blood radiated
questions.solution: Correct Answer (D) All of the above Irradiation Cellular components should be irradiated in order to reduce the risk of post transfusion GVHD when a patient is identified as being at risk for GVHD • For all immunosuppressed patients including bone marrow transplant (BMT) patients • When blood from a blood relative is used. • In case of exchange transfusion following intra uterine transfusion. The minimum dose delivered to the blood bag should be 25 Gy + 2

questions.text: Most common reaction associated with blood transfusion is
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) Febrile non hemolytic transfusion reaction The most frequent reaction associated with the transfusion of cellular blood components is a febrile nonhemolytic transfusion reaction (FNHTR). These reactions are characterized by chills and rigors and a more than 1 deg C rise in temperature. FNHTR is diagnosed when other causes of fever in the transfused patient are ruled out. Antibodies directed against donor leukocyte and HLA antigens may mediate these reactions; thus multiply transfused patients and multiparous women are felt to be at increased risk This can be reduced by use of leuco-depleted blood (produced using WBC filters)

questions.text: All are true about post transfusion purpura except
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) Less than 5 days after platelet transfusion This reaction presents as thrombocytopenia 7 – 10 days after platelet transfusion and occurs predominantly in women. Platelet-specific antibodies are found in the recipient’s serum, and the most frequently recognized antigen is HPA-la found on the platelet glycoprotein IIIa receptor. The delayed thrombocytopenia is due to the production of antibodies that react to both donor and recipient platelets. Additional platelet transfusions can worsen the thrombocytopenia and should be avoided. Treatment with intravenous immunoglobulin may neutralize the effector antibodies, or plasmapheresis can be used to remove the antibodies

questions.text: All are true about transfusion in a patient with IgA deficiency except
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) IgA rich plasma given Patients who are IgA-deficient, < 1 % of the population, may be sensitized to this Ig class and are at risk for anaphylactic reactions associated with plasma transfusion. Individuals with severe IgA deficiency should therefore receive only IgA-deficient plasma and washed cellular blood components. Patients who have anaphylactic or repeated allergic reactions to blood components should be tested for IgA deficiency.

questions.text: Genes for A and B antigens are on
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) 9q The first blood group antigen systemrecognized in 1900 was ABO, the most important in transfusion medicine. The major blood groups of this system are A, B, AB, and O. 0 type RBCs lack A or B antigens. These antigens are carbohydrates attached to a precursor backbone, may be found on the cellular membrane either as glycosphingolipids or glycoproteins, and are secreted into plasma and body fluids as glycoproteins. H substance is the immediate precursor on which the A and B antigens are added. This H substance is formed by the addition of fucose to the glycolipid or glycoprotein backbone. The subsequent addition of N-acetylgalactosamine creates the A antigen, whereas the addition of galactose produces the B antigen. The genes that determine the A and B phenotypes are found on chromosome 9q and are expressed in a Mendelian codominant manner. The gene products are glycosyl transferases, which confer the enzymatic capability of attaching the specific antigenic carbohydrate Individuals who lack the “A” and “B” transferases are phenotypically type “0,” whereas those who inherit both transferases are type “AB.” Rare individuals lack the H gene, which codes for fucose transferase, and cannot form H substance. These individuals are homozygous for the silent h allele (hh) and have Bombay phenotype (Oh)’

questions.text: Interval between 2 apharesis should be
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) 48 hours The recommended interval between two apheresis procedures is 48 hours. This time frame allows the donor's body to replenish the components that were removed during the apheresis. The 48-hour period ensures that the donor is able to safely donate again without putting their health at risk. This guideline is typically followed for platelet apheresis, where the body's platelet count needs to recover adequately. Incorrect Responses: B. 6 weeks: 6 weeks is typically the minimum interval between whole blood donations, not apheresis. For platelet apheresis, the recovery time required is much shorter—usually 48 hours—because only specific components (platelets) are collected, and the body’s ability to recover is quicker than after whole blood donations. C. 12 weeks: 12 weeks is the recommended interval for whole blood donations, not apheresis. In the case of apheresis, the required time for recovery is shorter, as the donation process only removes certain components (e.g., platelets or plasma), and the body can regenerate these faster compared to whole blood. D. 20 weeks: A 20-week interval is unnecessarily long for apheresis. For platelet donation via apheresis, a 48-hour interval is sufficient. This long period is more appropriate for situations like donating whole blood or for certain other components, but not for the apheresis procedures where the body recovers faster.

questions.text: Shelf life of RBCs stored in CPDA is
questions.solution: Correct Answer (C) 35 days The shelf life of red blood cells (RBCs) stored in CPDA (Citrate Phosphate Dextrose Adenine) is 35 days. CPDA is a commonly used preservative solution that helps maintain the viability and function of RBCs during storage. The addition of adenine in CPDA helps extend the storage period by providing a source of energy for the red blood cells, thus prolonging their shelf life to 35 days. Incorrect Responses: A. 21 days: RBCs stored in CPDA have a shelf life of 35 days, not 21 days. While 21 days is the shelf life of RBCs stored in citrate-phosphate-dextrose (CPD) solution (without adenine), the addition of adenine extends the shelf life by an additional 14 days. Therefore, 21 days is not correct for RBCs in CPDA. B. 28 days: 28 days is not the correct shelf life for RBCs stored in CPDA. It is closer to the shelf life of RBCs stored in a solution called CPD-SAG (Citrate Phosphate Dextrose with Saline and Adenine Glucose), but in CPDA, RBCs are viable for up to 35 days, not 28 days. D. 42 days: The shelf life of 42 days is typically seen in RBCs stored in additive solutions like SAG-M (saline-adenine-glucose-mannitol), which are not the same as CPDA. While RBCs stored in these newer solutions can last up to 42 days, CPDA specifically allows for 35 days of storage, not 42.

questions.text: Platelet transfusion should be completed within
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) 60 minutes Platelet transfusions should be completed within 60 minutes of initiation. This is because platelets are stored at room temperature (20-24°C) and are susceptible to bacterial contamination if kept for longer periods. To minimize the risk of bacterial growth and ensure the safety and efficacy of the transfusion, platelet transfusions are recommended to be completed within 1 hour. Incorrect Responses: B. 4 hours: While 4 hours might be a reasonable duration for some transfusion types, platelets are more prone to contamination at room temperature. Therefore, transfusions should not exceed 60 minutes, as a 4-hour window increases the risk of bacterial growth and a decrease in platelet functionality. C. 6 hours: A 6-hour duration is too long for a platelet transfusion. As mentioned, platelets are stored at room temperature and should be transfused as soon as possible, ideally within 1 hour. Extending the transfusion time increases the risk of complications like bacterial infection. D. 8 hours: Similar to the 4-hour and 6-hour options, 8 hours is much too long for platelet transfusions. Prolonged exposure to room temperature for this length of time is unsafe and can lead to a higher risk of bacterial contamination and platelet dysfunction

questions.text: A study of transfusion reactions reveals that some patients experienced an increase in body temperature that was greater than 1°C, accompanied by chills and hypotension. Blood cultures are positive for bacterial organisms. These patients respond to antibiotic therapy.Which of the following types of blood products did they most likely receive?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (D) Platelets Because platelets must be stored at room temperature, any contamination that occurred at the time of collection, such as bacterial skin flora of the donor, is more likely to cause sepsis in the recipient. The other products listed are refrigerated, which reduces bacterial growth. The causative agent of syphilis,Treponema pallidum, is often killed at refrigerator temperatures.
